description.text:
Plasma Laser Hologram Sword (Idea)

Reference Site
https://phys.org/news/2006-02-japanese-device-laser-plasma-3d.html

Derived from letter forms, namely a section of a capitol G and S, this chair shows how form can be generated from letters into sculptural furniture forms. It was a project I did along with a classmate for school.
The goal was to learn how to make things in Rhino, save them as an STL for printing, lay out pieces for laser cutting and milling setup. In the end we had produced 3 models, one for each process.
See the photos for the finished pieces.

Print the STL. It will print fairly well without support but there are a few nasty overhangs. Printing with one extra shell might help support it.
The AI files are for laser cutting 3mm thick material, in my case it was cardboard but you could use various plastics or wood. There is an AI file for milling out of 3/4 birch ply.
I have included the source file for those who are interested.

The Cozmo Robot is awesome! This is the plate necessary to make robot attachments to the cozmo lifter.

This is a "Z height" adjustable mounting bracket for the BLTouch. It is specifically designed for the CR-10 and for those who have not modified the Hot End. It may work for some who have made modifications; you should be able to tell by looking at the photos. It uses the existing Hot End Mounting Bracket screw, so you only need pair of M3 screws and hex nuts.***update. Use nylock nuts or add lock washers or use a dab of loctite. Vibration will cause the regular hex nuts to loosen.

I have printed and modified it several times to ensure everything fits properly. This is V.3 and I am confident of the fit at these print settings. The cap is only for aesthetics and covers M3x8 hardware.

Nothing fancy or showy about this design, but it works. This is thin and light, but sturdy enough to do the job it is designed to do. If you crash your bed, which may happen some day, this should break away and save your BLTouch from being damaged.

About 40 minutes to print at .2 and 80 mm/s print speed.

Printer:

Creality CR-10 S3

description.text:
Imported the original designs into tinkercad, after much slicing, cutting, rearranging, pasting, and joining...you see the result

I recommend a USB to SATA Portable Adapter it can be 2.0 or 3.0 mainly because the choke point for data flow will always be the 100Mb/s transfer thru the network connection

I recommend DietPi as the OS, but Armbian is very very good as well

I plan on using one of the packages in DietPi to setup a personal headless "cloud" server to be able to upload photos remotely to save space on my phone, also could be a NAS or whatever

-Update 08/07/17 found I had reversed the daggum layer..the USB and the Ethernet were on the wrong side for the opening of the harddrive, corrected. Added a vent from the OPi PC to the harddrive for airflow...the OPi PC fits too snugly into the case lid and would not allow airflow from the 40mm fan to the HD space.

-Update -FINAL- 08/19/17 the top had a tiny cutout in the air vent...corrected and uploaded the top fixed and full fixed. Printed, very tight fit with PLA, if printed in ABS may need to scale up X and Y by maybe 101% (or more depending on shrinkage)

comments.text: A "personal headless cloud server for photos" IS a NAS. Storage connected to a network is a NAS. Perhaps that's why they call Network Attached Storage NAS.

title: Sliding Lock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Is an OBJ file. It contains everything in the images. It is broken into three parts. The sliding lock is to be added to your next project. The scale of the lock is 3.35 x 0.8 x 2.95 inches. Scale this to fit your needs. Use one of your favorite software packages and boolean/ append it to the top and bottom of your case. The pegs on the side keep the lock from sliding off the rails. The sliding lock is made to be reversible. So you can flip the lock for left or right handed individuals. Put your favorite text or logo on the front of the lock. This was part of another project I made. Check it out if you would like to know more.
See the link to find examples of how this is attached. A note when you are attaching these objects. The only parts that should be booleaned are the pegs and the rails. One rail and peg set per side of the case.

description.text:
Whirlpool cabrio agitator hub.

custom i3 knockoff

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

My whirlpool cabrio platnium washer took a crap on me yesterday. The washer keept giving me an error code of "Sd" or "5d". After browsing online for a bit i found out that the agitator at the bottom of the drum shouldn't just free wheel but be connected to the drum and spin together. I watched a video on how to pull the agitator out and check the hub as a video instructed. it was a very simple procedure and took maybe 10 mins. i found the hub and removed it only to find the internal splines were completely gone. i found replacements online for $20 or so but i needed my washer now. The part didn't look that difficult to make so i went into TinkerCad and designed and printed using Cura I didn't spend a lot of time with the design because i just needed the part right away so i sort of guessed as i went along while taking measurements of the original part. i had to file it a little and the internal spline tolerance is tight so it had to be persuaded with a hammer to fit on the shaft. after it was all back together I've run several loads in my washer without a problem. i'm hoping someone else can be saved with this part and maybe make it a little better. Not sure how long it will last yet but i'm sure i'll know soon enough.

comments.text: well it's been a week and its still working. :)

author: danman24

print_settings.Notes:: This is for a Maker Select Ultimate IIIP  which is the same as a Wanhao Duplicator 6 but only the Wanhao is a choice here so I put that as my printer.

description.text:
A simple 3D printer filament guide that keeps the filament 40mm from the back wall of a Monoprice Maker Select Ultimate or Wanhao Duplicator 6 style printer.

Double sided sticky tape is used to fix the guide to the back of the printer near the top.

VERSION 2: Version 2 now posted (and preferred) has a stronger base so it does not crack off easily. It also has a slot because I often found I wanted to take the filament out of the loop if I decided I needed to feed the reel from higher than the printer (like for really flexible materials you cannot just put the reel in the back with good results).

This guide has solved a problem where some filaments like very full 1.1lb reals of ABS could have the filament last few loops around a very full spool come between the spool and the back wall of the printer leading to filament being too hard too pull to the head and a failed print.

The filament is routed through the hole on it's way to the print head for a cleaner feed.

Tip: On smaller reels that are really full I pull off a lot of the material and put it aside in the same bag I store the reel. This makes it less likely to slip outside of the reel and then bind because it is not on the reel.

If you find this is useful feel free to drop a comment or even a buck using the ThingIverse paypal gratuity system shown as a download is started. Mostly I want this to be helpful to people using this part. Enjoy!

For really small 'gratuities' since thingiverse does a huge $3 or more for paypal (too much IMHO) you may use bitcoin address 1yKJcrkLE7RmsLmZPL3ku5PpazGzNmDSS or Ethereum address 0xbCCEf017Ff00215496A768fb0238893Edf7584B0 but no worries or expectations, key thing is you find this useful! Enjoy!

description.text:
With my December trip overseas coming up i thought i might come up with something to insulate the plugs on my Lipo batteries for flight.

I figure taping up the xt60 and balance plug would probably work well enough but, i have a 3d printer!

I was going to add some sort of clip system to it but as i was using pla it is quite brittle and was scared of the clips breaking off and basically making the whole thing useless.

all that is needed to hold together is a 100mm cable tie and an elastic band to fasten to battery.

description.text:
A Dark Eldar Raider skimmer transport thingy for Epic Armageddon.

Print one of everything except the 'blade' item (print three). Glue to assemble. Season to taste. Serve hot. Full models supplied as a visual guide.
I'm still not planning on playing dark eldar myself; model inspired by discussion with a fellow Epicer.

couple of pics of printout including one with guard and dread for scale.
In the printed sample i used the venom base from here... https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2285808

i will be adding the low-poly dark eldar infantry soon, just want to clean up the files a little. most of the spikey details are lost during print (no surprise there) but they produce a vaguely humaniod form. FullB stl has the infantry in situ.

comments.text:
Looks great, ive printed one off, bit fiddly for my tastes, but ive mucked about on tinkercad with a version split in half for easy print/ glue.
Am running a test print and then if that works i'll upload it as a remix.
I also used tinkercad to extra the warrior on the side and put him on small base for warrior kabals, had the same issue as you about the spikes and i tweaked it a little. When thats tested i'll upload that too in the remixes :)
comments.author: Beregrond2

comments.text:
hey beregrond2,
saw your split model version. i have tried split models (when working on a different but similar model) and found the tapered bits (prow, sail etc) would end up too thin and too narrow which is why i made them individual 'lumps'. but if split works on your printer then it definitely can make assembly easier.
comments.author: Beregrond2

comments.text: I found with doing spikes etc on such a small scale model, it helps to increase the scale on them, it might look silly in proportion, but when you look at the model in the slice it might actually have them picked out slightly rather than not at all

description.text:
This is a light diffuser for a Tecline US-16 dive torch. The torch has originally a very bright light that has a distinct spot. For video and photo its a bit hard to get even lighting.

I have made this diffuser from white PLA. There diffuser itself is just 0,3mm thick so it will be interesting to see if it will hold to easily damaged.

I made a little ring so I can attach a string to it so I can take it of during a dive.

I have not tested it under water yet, but my test in a dark room is promising as the photos shows.
I'm also thinking about one with a dome shaped diffuser.

title: Anet A8 - Creative Live! Sync Webcam - Mount

description.text:
Simple mount I designed for my Creative Live! Sync HD webcam to do timelapses and video streams for monitoring on my Anet A8.

The bottom flap of the camera pops into the little slot at the top, and the slots at the bottom slide onto the undercarriage of the print bed. I was just doing this for kicks to see if I could do it without using any mounting hardware or disassembling the bed, but I'm surprised at how well it works.

The timelapse (https://youtu.be/2asKcHkQmRo) shows the printing of the final version of the mount. It was taken with a very loose but workable previous version of the camera mount.

title: Da Vinci 1.0 Pro MKS and Pi Mount

description.text:
When I replaced the electronics inside my Da Vinci 1.0 pro, I designed this bracket to mount an MKS 1.4 and a Raspberry Pi 3. The mount is simple in design, and is quite flimsy until fitted. Use M3 screws to fit the bracket to the frame (you may find it easier to open out some of the mounting holes), and self-tapping screws to fix the MKS and Pi boards to the bracket. The uprights to the left of the bracket are used to fit a 40mm cooling fan.

If you like my work, please consider a small donation (a dollar or so) to support my other projects.

title: Raspberry PI 3 Box - Big Passive Cooling

description.text:
This is a passive cooled (with a costume big 28mm x 28mm x 15mm heat sink) Raspberry PI 3 box with a "Clamp" on the long side. I did not find any box fasten this way and not along the long side. I used (a variation of) this on my "MagicMirror" project: https://photos.app.goo.gl/FUoiEjMmNBIay1Xk1

Note 1: The lid "pushes" on the heat sink (from the top) so it is always pressured down against the small plate, the plate is then pushed against the CPU so the heat transfers better.

Note 2: Remember to put some heat paste on both the CPU and the small plate.

You will need a heat sik that fits: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Heatsink-28x28x15mm-Aluminum-heatsink-heat-sink-radiator-for-Electronic-Chipset-heat-dissipation/32712732874.html

And a 20mm x 20mm x 3mm copper (or aluminum) plate to transfer the heat to the heat sink, you can use two of these maybe (but make sure they stick together): https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10-pcs-20mmx20mm-0-3mm-to1-5mm-Heatsink-Copper-Shim-Thermal-Pads-for-Laptop-GPU/32806314067.html

I'm using a single 4mm thick copper plate as a heat transfer plate. But in the design I made it for a 3mm thick plate so you could use the ones above.

In the SketchUp files you can find a 28x28 mm version and a 38x38 mm version. :)

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

No

No

0.2

20%

Clean out the 3mm holes

You will need to clean out the 3mm M3 nut trap holes. I'm using a 0.2 layer to get the nut trap to look nice. :) I also drill out the RPi3 holes to 3mm so I can fit an M3 screw though them.

description.text:
I wanted to learn T-Splines so I started to model a duck. I liked the model but wanted to go further. It is summer so why not make a beer stand / chiller! Pour some ice inside the duck, place your beer and enjoy the cold beverage.

The chilling function is actually working very well. I had the duck in the sauna and there was still ice cubes left when leaving after one hour. This is probably because the walls are thick and filled with air -> great insulation.

description.text:
This radio tray is for the ImpulseRC Alien 5" quadcopter, to help tidy up the installation of the radio equipment in the quad. The Alien Quadcopter range can be found here https://impulserc.com/collections/alien. This design will allow you to mount your VTX & RX simply and makes for a very tidy installation. The design caters for both the RH & LH side SMA VTX's and you can always install an LED in the other spare hole...

However, I should say there are two schools of thought on the solution;

  1. mounting the radio kit, RX & VTX close together is not a good idea as may cause intermodulation product and the possibility of the VTX power over driving the sensitive front of the RX, (FGA) resulting in blocking and a reduction in range,
  2. the other view suggests that there is no impact based on practical experience (LeDrib)... I would suggest that you make your own checks and draw your conclusions. But for me, and my flying it works...

@finalglideaus - suggests you should separate your RX & VTX if you are going to fly long distances - Chad likes the idea of radio hardware & the antenna of the two systems being mounted as far apart as possible.

Drew's view is that it all seems to work well, even when mounted close together, and Drew has not had a lockout yet...
@drewcamden - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HltLZR9lMbQ
Move to about 23 mins 41 secs in the video.

This design was inspired by @drewcamden aka LeDrib... http://shop.miniquadclub.com/shop/accessories/mqc-fusion-commdock/

Drew's 'commdock' was designed for the MiniQuadClub Fusion Frame - http://shop.miniquadclub.com/shop/frames/mqc-fusion/

This radio tray has been designed specifically for the Alien 5". And has a number of features Drews doesn't have in his design namely; a front & rear brace structure, square holes in the rear brace to help align the VTX, a reduced diameter rear plug in the RX antenna tube hole to help locate RX antenna tubes. This is the 3rd iteration of this design which has been optimised to print with TPU using 2mm support structures...

Please follow Drews channels...
Twitter @Drewcamden
Facebook https://www.facebook.com/andrew.camden
YouTube https://www.youtube.com/LeDribFPV
Instagram https://www.instagram.com/drewcamden/

Please follow me...
Twitter - @heliboy
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/DavidOwensuk
YouTube - https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCu8jFGkgTAqEUlK7dj1jhxw
Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/dowens234/

As always please; download, like and subscribe... Please feedback if you would like changes made to the design.

title: Active coal filter holder for 120mm computer fan

description.text:
3D printers melt plastic and it doesn´t smell so nice. To tacle this problem I have always had active coal filter by the printer. After moving the printer to a new place it was time to make a better filter holder.

This one is a big one with a big area for the filter material. I use a active coal sheet made for over the oven fans. A sheet costs a couple of € and lasts for years. Thickness is 7 mm.

In the bottom of the holder is a standard 120mm computer fan which is drawing air in through the filters (so that the dust gets collected on the outside of the filter.

In the files is the complete holder + top and the holder cut into four pieces. I made it from the four pieces and glued them together.

Glue the thing together, Install a 120mm fan with four screws and cut pieces of active coal filter and install.

comments.author: raedonlpa

comments.text:
Bueno, decir que la impresora lleva semiacabada unas 3 semanas, digo semi, por que hay algún que otro fallo de acople de piezas (los agujeros de los tornillos no roscan algunos (sobre todo los soportes de Y, el carro de X he tenido que modificar un poco para acoplar el esxtrusor que tenia en la anet, que es el HTA3D, y voy a colocar otras dos guías para Z, con probablemente doble motor de Z, y quizás varilla de 10mm o 12 para aportar mayor rigidez, estoy esperando casquillos de la medida de los LM8UU, para reemplazarlos, ya que he visto que alguno esta en mal estado, y bota un poco durante el recorrido haciendo que el hotend bote un poco sobre la capa actual, pedí unos LM8UU pero de los 12 que pedí llegaron 11 en mal estado, total, a devolverlos, de ahí la solución de casquillos de esa medida.
También queda por resolver temas de vibraciones durante la impresión, que aún habiendo puesto la impresora sobre dos laminas de goma eva para amortiguar, siguen estando ahí, y por mucho que cambio aceleraciones y velocidades, no desaparecen, la cama también vibra, para ello, probablemente sustituya todas las escuadras impresas por escuadras metálicas para el perfil, con esas modificaciones, espero que el peso añadido, y la solidez, resuelvan el tema. Por cierto, cuando esté hecho, las prometidas fotos.
Un saludo.

comments.author: JuanCarlos_3design

comments.text:
Yo por comodidad con el tema de las tuercas y por economía, he pedido el tipo B, ya que en Aliexpress he cogido 200 tuercas tipo martillo por unos escasos 8 euros, es mas fácil encontrarlas en métrica 5 que las necesarias para el tipo I cuya ranura es de 5mm en vez de los 6 que tiene el perfil de tipo B, a pesar de que a priori pueden llegar a valer prefiero ir a lo seguro.
Yo contacte con el a través de un comentario por sus videos de youtube, por temas de las guías de las piezas inferiores, que llevan muesca para el perfil, y me dijo que eran perfectamente validos, así que, yo si fuera tu, cogeria tipo B.
Cuando me vayan llegando las cosas, empezaré con el montaje, he pedido varillas también, para asegurar que no estén dobladas, por si las que tiene la maquina lo están, ya que al precio que están en rational stock, merece la pena, estoy mirando también incluir en mi lista de la compra unos casquillos con las medidas exactas del LM8UU, ya que los he encontrado en 3DPenedes por 1,99 euros, a pesar de que tengo también los igus, pero estos, si entran un pelin duros en las piezas, no cumplen bien su función, al ser de un polímero que fácilmente se deforma, y en cualquier caso, los casquillos serian una mejora importante respecto a los rodamientos LM8UU.
Cama caliente, también cogere nueva, total, añadir 17 euros mas, lo único que añade realmente a la ecuación es casi casi, tener 2 impresoras, pero solo una electronica.
Bueno, que me he liado mucho, cuando la tenga montada, la pondré aquí, ya que considero que es un trabajazo lo que ha hecho JuanCarlos, y merece como mínimo, que los que realicemos su montaje, lo mostremos, y compartamos la experiencia, y el rendimiento logrado.
Un saludo.

description.text:
The Ormerod threaded rod for the z-axis always seemed a bit problematic so I decided to upgrade it for a lead screw. To avoid using a shaft connector where space is tight, I decided to use a lead screw integral to the motor and bought this one from Oooznest.
http://ooznest.co.uk/3D-Printer-Electronic-Parts/Motors/ACME-Screw-NEMA17-Stepper-Motor
Initially I went with the standard brass nut but was not happy with it so changed it out for the delrin anti-backlash block.
http://ooznest.co.uk/ACME-Anti-Backlash-Nut-Block?search=anti%20backlash%20nut
The nut block was far too tight so I screwed it onto an offcut of the lead screw and gently heated the lead screw until it ran free.
Clearances are tight and if you use a different solution for the your sensor you may need to make adjustments.
My sensor solution can be found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1545576
The lead screw is on the same plane as the original Y Axis but is further away from the motor in the X Axis. To accommodate this I had to make a slightly longer homing pad.

Changes to the config file needed
M569 P2 S0 ; Set Z motor direction
M92 X87.4890 Y87.4890 Z400 ; Set axis steps/mm for TR 8*8

WARNING! The original Ormerod solution allowed the Z nut to pop free if you crashed the head into the bed. This solution means that is no longer the case, all you have is the small amount of lift allowed by the rotation of the head on the rail.

https://pinshape.com/items/18502-3d-printed-ormerod-2-tr8-directdrive-z-axis-redesign was a source of ideas for this upgrade.

print_settings.Notes:: It prints well in either PLA or ABS

description.text:
This is a simple PCB or model makers drill press. I decided I didn't need a complicated rack and pinion a simple push lever would do.

There are two motor mounts, one plain and one with a hole to take a sub miniature toggle switch.

The pillars are made from 5mm rod salvaged from an old printer. You will need to ease the sliding parts with a needle file to make them a good fit and slide easily without being loose. A spray of silicone furniture polish when done will help lubricate them.
The spring is from a bottle of hand wash.
The base I used is a perspex block designed for rubber stamping. Drill and tap the holes slowly, if you start to see any distortion around the hole while drilling or tapping, back out and let everything cool. I have included an alternative base for those who wish to print one.

The motor and chuck were a cheap £5 job from China but the chuck runs surprisingly true.
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Electric-Hand-Drill-set-DC12V-Motor-Twist-Drill-Bit-Keyless-Chuck-Grinder-Chuck/172443189940?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

I have since found the paper feed motor from a HP printer is about the same diameter but with a bit more grunt, though you won't need it for drilling PCBs.

Depending on your power source you may want to put a diode across the motor terminals.

All screws are 4mm pan head.

Now added a top for the drill. It takes a rocker switch requiring a 6.8 x 19mm cutout.

Printer:

Ormerod 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Take note of the orientation of the stop piece when printing. The extension for the lever must lie flat on the bed as shown. If you print it in the upright orientation (as assembled) the lever will tend to split the layers.

It prints well in either PLA or ABS

comments.text: What is the length of the bars?
comments.author: olo2000pm

comments.text: On the model shown they are about 15 cm but as long as they are equal and more than about 10 cm it doesn't matter. Obviously the longer they are the bigger the capacity under the drill. I probably wouldn't go much above 15 - 20 cm though as twist in the rods when pulling on the lever will start to become significant. Anything bigger and you would probably need a third rod secured at the top and bottom or better still a different design.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:322720

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=322720

Using the following options:

image_thickness = 2
n_facets = 21
cylinder_height = 50
background = dark
direction = outside
surface_file = lithocylinder220170805-11612-cj9c1w-0.dat
extrusion_width = 0.4

When printing from a model, it is interesting to know how well the real object printed matches the sizes specified in the model. Here, I created many measurements in all 3 x-y-z directions and with common structures: cubes, cylinders and cylindrical holes.
We have:
10, 15, 20, 25 and 30 mm in X and Y directions.
3, 5, and 10 mm in the Z direction
3, 5, and 10 mm in diameters of cylinders
3, 5, and 10 mm in diameters of cylindrical holes.

I guess you can also create one for non metric cases from the openScad model.
Feel free to make alterations.

Enclosed is the OpenScad model and the resulting STL file from it.
I also have a youtube movie to explain and show how well my Anet A8 printer driven by CURA does.

Printer:

Anet-A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%
The final object.

Measurements We compare models designed for printing, and the resulting real world object being printed. The transition from the virtual mathematical world to the real one is sensitive to many factors such as the algorithms used to convert the model to printer instructions that move the head, extrude the material flow and steps along lines to outline the object and fill its inside, layer by layer. How well does this process convey our designed model? Lets print it and than measure it with our tools and validate the accuracy of our printer and the entire process. We can learn how different directions (X, Y, and Z) are sensitive to errors, how well common structures like cylinders, cubes and holes are sensitive, learn to use measurement tools, and perhaps even design new experiments to model and measure other aspects of the process. For instance - how about a cube rotated by 45 degrees on the Z axis, or multiple axes?

what we need Any printing material such as PLA are enough.
Tools needed is only a caliper, preferred a digital one, as seen in the picture. We only need a measurement tool such as this digital Caliper.

• measuring
  • sizes
  • dimensions
30 minutes

Review the model in openScad
View the STL file
Print the object (1-2 hours).

Write down your measurements, assess the results, explain the errors.
Assess how pupil progresses with these tasks.

remixed_from.title: Throw-away slick wheel for RC car (Traxxas E-Revo 1:16 but adaptable)

title: Voronoi microstructure RC wheel (Traxxas E-Revo 1:16 but adaptable)

description.text:
Voronoi microstructure RC wheels

Original design: Lennart Rolland.
For project: OctoMY™ (http://octomy.org).
Description: This is an iteration of a series of experimental designs for 3D printed wheels for Traxxas E-Revo 1:16 RC car. It is designed to be easily adaptable to other RC cars. This model is parametric, and the parameters are commented in the scad file.

Driving: I have tested my car with 4 of these wheels mounted, and I can tell you it is hilarious to drive! It takes some practice to get used to, but once you are there, its drifting time baby! My car does not have a central diff, I think that would be really beneficial. The wheels are sturdy as hell, but the pattern wears off pretty quickly. It doesn't break of, it sort of smears out to become smoother which is nice. While driving you will notice that you have to go really easy on the throttle to get it going, once it is up to speed you can start drifting about. Similarly, small nudges on the steering is all it takes to steer. I think these wheels forces you to become a better driver.

Please note: This is a prototype design that may have been superseded by better ideas.

Pros

  • Most of the problems of the last tire have been fixed and more. (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2450118)
  • It fit the wheel mount of the car after... N iterations.
  • The low mass made it really accelerate fast.
  • The slick design was fun to drive.
  • The internal voronoi structure made the wheels really rigid and stood up to some severe punishment.

Cons

  • They look kind of ugly
  • I think future iterations will have more contact area with the ground

Overal: Albeit the obvious room for improvement I am still quite happy with the result!

Standard disclaimer: This work is provided as a convenience and for informational purposes only. The original author assumes no responsibility for any adverse effects that may arrise from this work.

Copyright / license: I hereby place this work into the public domain, though if you want to show appreciation and you have robot parts to spare, please consider donating them to the OctoMY™ project http://www.octomy.org/contribute/donation ).

Printer:

Creality CR10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height, $fn=100

Infill:

100% (infill pattern is part of model)

Notes:

See attached screenshot of the settings I used in Cura.

BE CAREFUL!

If you use too low tolerance (setting in the top of the OpenSCAD file) the following will happen to you:

  • Wheel not fitting to the car at all (tolerance < 0.1 mm)
  • Wheel fitting so snugly that parts of the car will have to be pried of with specialized tools when removing the tire again (tolerance < 0.2 mm)

See photos on how I had to struggle to fix this on one of my prints.

Tools I needed. I even had to make my own using old bike spokes. Using specialized tools to pry of the hex hub nut thingy from the car. How a healty hub-nut thingy is supposed to look like How a removed hub nut thingy looks like :-)

OpenSCAD <3

Since I am a developer by day, I tend to like that way of thinking, so OpenSCAD is perfect for me. I am falling in love...

Anyway, I tried to make the wheel in a "modular" approach where each module is somewhat documented and reusable. Please see comments in the original OpenSCAD file attached.

Basically there are 5 parts:

  • Outer hollow tire shell to keep everything together
  • Solid core cylinder as a sound structural element in the middle
  • Voronoi spoke pattern cutout for carving out the interesting internal structure
  • Cutout for tire pattern on outside rim of tire for more grip
  • Cutout for hexagonal hub connector on Traxxas car. This seems to be standardized across many Traxxas cars. Changing this one single cutout will make this tire work for other brands or cars.

Here is full code of the main file for searchability:

tolerance=0.2;
$fn=100;

function hex_dia(dia) = dia * ( 2 / sqrt (3) );
function normalize(v) = v/(sqrt(v[0]*v[0] + v[1]*v[1]));

// General purpose 2D voronoi generator
module voronoi(points, L=200, thickness=0.2, round=6){
    for (p=points){
        difference(){
            minkowski(){
            intersection_for(p1=points){
                if (p!=p1){
                    translate((p+p1)/2 - normalize(p1-p) * (thickness+round)){
                    angle=90+atan2(p[1]-p1[1], p[0]-p1[0]);
                        rotate([0,0,angle])
                        translate([-L,-L])
                        square([2*L, L]);
                    }
                }
            }
            circle(r=round);
            }

        }
    }
}

// Generate a 2D support structure suited for a wheel
module voronoi_structure(diameter=80, width=45, spokes=11, thickness=0.2, mid_stages=1, stagger_skew=0.2, hub_clearance=0.5, rim_clearance=0.1, hub_multiplier=1, rim_multiplier=1, round=3){
    radius=diameter/2;
    inner_radius=radius*hub_clearance;
    rim_radius=radius*(1.0-rim_clearance);
    radius_range=radius-inner_radius-(radius-rim_radius);
    stages=mid_stages+2;
    stage_radius=radius_range/stages;
    stagger_offset=(360.0/spokes)*stagger_skew;
    point_set_hub = [ 
        for (a = [0 : 360.0/(spokes*hub_multiplier): 360.0])
            inner_radius *  [ sin(a), cos(a) ]
    ];

    point_set_rim = [ 
        for (a = [0 : 360.0/(spokes*rim_multiplier): 360.0])
            radius *  [ sin(a), cos(a) ]
    ];

    point_set_mid=(mid_stages>0)?
        [ 
            for (stage = [1 : mid_stages])
                for (a = [0 : 360.0/spokes: 360.0])
                    (inner_radius+(stage_radius * stage)) * [ sin(a+((0!=(stage%2))?stagger_offset:0)), cos(a+((0!=(stage%2))?stagger_offset:0)) ]
        ]:
        [];
    point_set=concat([[0,0]], point_set_hub, point_set_mid, point_set_rim);
    voronoi(points=point_set, L=radius*1.5, thickness=0.2, round=round);
}

// Generate a 3D extrusion of the support structure above
module voronoi_extrusion(diameter=80, width=22.5, spokes=11, thickness=0.2, mid_stages=1, stagger_skew=0.2, hub_clearance=0.5, rim_clearance=0.1, hub_multiplier=1, rim_multiplier=1, twist=30.0, scaling=1.0, slices=1, round=3){
    linear_extrude(height = width, center = false, convexity = 10, scale=scaling, twist=twist, slices=slices)
        voronoi_structure(diameter, width, spokes, thickness, mid_stages, stagger_skew, hub_clearance, rim_clearance, hub_multiplier, rim_multiplier, round);
}

// Create a cylider with rounded edges
module tire(diameter=80, width=45, factor=0.2){
    //ifactor=(1.0-factor);
    rounding=width*factor;
    color("purple")translate([0,0,rounding/2])minkowski(){
        cylinder( d=diameter-rounding, h=width-rounding);
        sphere(r=rounding/2);
    }
    //translate([0,diameter*1.3,0])cylinder(h=width, d=diameter);
    //translate([0,0, width*1.3])cylinder(h=width, d=diameter);
}

// Create a hollow cylinder with rounded edges
module hollow_tire(diameter=80, width=45, factor=0.2, side_thickness=4, rubber_thickness=4){
    difference(){
        tire(diameter=diameter,width=width, factor=factor);
        translate([0,0,side_thickness/2])tire(diameter=diameter-rubber_thickness,width=width-side_thickness, factor=factor);
    }
}

// This is the part that makes the wheel fit a Traxxas RC car. You can tweak this to make it fit any other RC car you like
// NOTE: The tolerances are 0.2 mm and specified in the top of the document. Anything lower is bound to give you troubles like:
//       + Wheel not fitting to the car at all (tolerance < 0.1 mm)
//       + Wheel fitting so snugly that parts of the car will have to be pried of with specialized tools when removing the tire again (tolerance < 0.2 mm)

module wheel_mount_cutout_traxxas_hex(hex_h=5,hole_h=4, hex_d=12, hole_d=4, total_h=0, od=20){
    h=max(hex_h+hole_h, total_h);
    d=max(max(hex_d, hole_d)*1.2+2, od);
    budge=1;
    factor=0.2;
    union(){
        translate([0,0,hole_h+hex_h])translate([0,0,0])cylinder(d=hex_d+tolerance, h=h);
        translate([0,0,0])cylinder(d=hole_d+tolerance, h=h+budge*2);
        translate([0,0,0])cylinder ($fn=6, h = hex_h+budge, r = hex_dia (hex_d + tolerance) / 2);
    }
}

// This is a cutout for the tire pattern (the knarly bits that actually grips the dirt)
// Tweak this to decide how many, and how big you want the knobs to be, or remove entirely for full slick mode
module pattern_cutout(diameter=80, width=45, tracks=3, groves=24, track_depth=2, track_width=6, grove_factor=0.5, margin=0.2){
    radius=diameter/2;
    grove_step=(diameter-(diameter*margin*2))/groves;
    track_step=(width-(width*margin*2)-track_width)/(tracks-1);
    union(){
        rotate_extrude(convexity=10){
            for(track=[0:tracks-1]){
                translate([radius-track_depth,margin*width+track_step*track,0])square([track_depth,track_width]);
            }
        }
        grove_step=360/groves;
        for(grove=[0:groves-1]){
            rotate([0,0,grove*grove_step])translate([radius,0,0])cylinder(d=track_depth*2, h=width);
        }
    }
}

// This is the top level module that generates a full tire
module complete_wheel(diameter=80, width=45, rim_in=27, spokes=12){
    thickness=1.5;
    hub_mount_d=20;
    rim_hole=diameter-10;
    hub_h=4;
    spoke_d=hub_mount_d;
    spoke_h=(diameter-hub_mount_d)/2;
    hex_h=3;
    hole_h=4;
    min_hub_mount_h=hole_h+hex_h;
    hub_mount_h=max(width,min_hub_mount_h);
    union(){
        difference(){
            union(){
                difference(){
                    hollow_tire(diameter=diameter, width=width, side_thickness=thickness, rubber_thickness=thickness*3);
                }
                cylinder(d=hub_mount_d, h=hub_mount_h);
                thick=1;
                difference(){
                    tire(diameter=diameter-thickness, width=width);
                    voronoi_extrusion(diameter=diameter, width=width, spokes=6, thickness=thick, mid_stages=2, stagger_skew=0.2, hub_clearance=0.4, rim_clearance=0.2, hub_multiplier=2, rim_multiplier=2, twist=0, scaling=1.0, round=thick*2);
                }
            }
            wheel_mount_cutout_traxxas_hex(hex_h=hex_h,hole_h=hole_h, hex_d=12, hole_d=4+tolerance, total_h=hub_mount_h, od=hub_mount_d);
            pattern_cutout(diameter=diameter, width=width, tracks=2, groves=50, track_depth=thickness*0.75, track_width=2, grove_factor=0.5, margin=0.15);
        }
    }
}

diameter=90;
width=10;
difference(){
    complete_wheel(diameter=diameter, width=width, rim_in=0);
    // Uncomment this to see a cutout of the wheel
    //sz=100;   translate([0,0,-sz/2])resize([sz,sz,sz])cube();
}

author: Pointy

title: Toy Cruiser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an easy to assemble toy car made using lots of high-tech tools. Once you 3D print, and laser cut your parts, the rest can be zip tied and bolted together in minutes. I was initially planning on making more of a hot rod. However, thanks to the slow speed of the servos, it turned out to be more of a cruiser. This vehicle has a slow smooth ride, which makes it the perfect motorized platform for all kinds of applications. For instance, it makes a great camera dolly (for silent films and music videos), and a suitable robot base. Learn more:
http://www.instructables.com/id/toy-cruiser/

The wooden bracket was laser cut on a 120W Epilog 36EXT printer with the following settings: power:75
speed:15
frequency: 500 The wheels were printed on an Object Connex 500 printer loaded with Vero White and Tango Black. The hubs used DM_8250_Grey40, and the tires used DM_9885_Shore85. Full parts list, assembly instructions, and demo videos can be found on the Instructables page:
http://www.instructables.com/id/toy-cruiser/

comments.text: rofl well... i thougth a good printer can do it but its somthing hard becouse the tolerances, so today i tryed by myself. could unmount one part but the other broke when i tryed to open it printing at 185º. but as it doesnt have tolerances between the top of one and the bottom of the other i guess its normal. it just fused. so its amazing you could print it and works well at first attempt :) maybe tomorrow i will test it again if i have some time  :)

comments.text: I was just asking you (will make it shorter) if you make a 20x20x10mm cube with a 3.4mm hole in the middle can you easily slip a 3mm bolt into it using that PLA?  Measure it with calipers and see if the cube is 20x20 as well.

comments.text: yeah ofcurse, it does 20,01-20,2, dependig of the test, filament, etc, sometimes even perfect 20. but as i said it fused the top and the bot of the separate parts doing it intro one. that was my issue when i tested
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: Normal tolerance is 3.4 and tight is 3.2 and loose is 3.6 or 3.8 I forget.  I wonder why it fuses on you?  I am using a 0.4mm nozzle btw.
comments.author: Ewokalvino

comments.text: told ya, no separation between the top of the holder and the bottom of the "opener" object (the stick). that made the fusion. i could dismount the  part that should click for open and close, but the part with the rounds fused 2 much and cracked because as i said, the bottom part with the upper from the holder have no tolerances between each other. maybe with a stronger material and better temps i could succes like you, anyway i have already 1.5m of chains made
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: Alright, here is a viable question and that is how are your holes?  If you make a hole 3.4mm will a 3mm machine bolt easily go through if the hole is from the build plate straight up?  What I mean is if you were to insert the bolt after printing but not removing the part the bolt would be standing straight up.
comments.author: Ewokalvino

comments.text: i would do 3.3 tolerance, maybe even 3.2-1 if i want it tight, the platform zone has many chances to need retouch with a cutter or somthing. sorry for not answering before, didnt even noticed this message.

description.text: Some foreign characters broke the toilet seat bracket by standing on the seat...  They sell these replacement brackets for around 1 to 5 Euro depending where you live. Usually though, they are hard to come by and a new seat must be purchased.

The item is divided into two parts which can be glued together or simply placed together insert the dowel pin and install on the toilet. This was done to allow for easier printing and support. I made the dowel pin hole slightly smaller to avoid any slack and to allow tweaking.

description.text:
I had a few 50 mm blower fans laying around, and it looks like they could produce better airflow than a common 40 mm fan, so I decided to design a mount for these. I'm using original E3D v6 Lite hot-end at the moment, and after a few test print it works well on my highly customised 3KU K3000 based delta.

The 120° heatsink mount is from ariuskooo

Doesn't Matter

200 micron

20%

Notes:

It's a bit tough to print; I ended up printing in a weird angle, this way only a minimum amount of support was needed (check the picture of the visualised G-code), and came out perfectly

The rest doesn't really matter, use I'd recommend using 3 wall perimeters on 0.4 nozzle.

Made in Fusion 360,
Bow is cut flat on the backside so that it can be oriented with this side down for printing flat. This allows it to have whatever kind of attachment you require just glued to it. I glued hair clips on for my daughter's hair.

Don't have a 3d printer? you can now order this bow on our Etsy Shop
https://www.etsy.com/listing/551384283/large-ravens-hair-bow-bow-tie?ref=shop_home_active_1

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

0-20%

Notes:

Printed in Simplify 3d 4.0 using variable layer processes.
1 process printed up to 1mm before the first top layer at 0% infill, then switched over to 20% for the rest of the print.

On back side of bow, I used 5 minute epoxy to fasten metal hair clip.
The same could be done for a bow tie attachment as well.
I printed at 75% for hair bow, scale as required for your printer, and needs.

title: Easy Loading Plywood Spool for Filament.

description.text: This spool uses 5mm thick plywood and is designed for cnc routing. All but the last side is glued together as a unit and the last side is held on with screws for easy loading.

I used a 1/8" endmill. The slats should be cut from the outside (tool offset) and the slots and holes from the inside. The smaller glue hub is cut from the outside and it's holes from the inside.
The files that end in TAP are the Gcode I used. I drive my router with Mach3. Maybe it will work for you. Be sure to use a 1/8" endmill and use a sacrificial piece under the plywood. It will cut deeper than the thickness of the plywood. There are no tabs, so you will need to hold the parts steady as they cut free.
I used 16" square blanks with screws in the corners to hold it in place.
The zip file is the original Solidworks 2011 part and assembly files. The zip is made with the Pack and Go function.

author: cipis

description.text: This model is .1 deeper within the hub nut. I had trouble getting on the nut to hold the wheel on.

title: ImpulseRC Alien Side Plate for Runcam Eagle 2 (and sorta Foxeer Arrow V3)

description.text:
WARNING: I don't actually have an Alien frame but I'm pretty sure this is a mm for mm clone. It's not a Martian or Martian II, it's something else and every part made for the Alien has fit to on this to the mm. I really think it's a TOTAL clone (unlike the martian).

DESIGNED FOR RUNCAM EAGLE V2 (its 3 2mm holes are 6mm apart).

For me, (in Taulman 910) even though the measurements, the Foxeer Arrow V3 also fits even though its holes are at a nice round 6.29mm apart (i mean - really?). In the photo above, you can see the Foxeer fits two holes pretty well (but not perfectly) - to get all three you'd need to file it a little bit.

I hope I don't anger the quad gods with this - the Alien, an icon of FPV Quads, has an excellent mounting bracket for your standard HS1177, Swift 2, etc... but the Eagle and Foxeer Arrow V3, not so much.

You can squeeze an Arrow V3 or an Eagle in there, but you're really bending the carbon to do so. Some may like that, but it was a little too much bending of carbon for me.

So I made this, admittedly it has very similar dimensions - are really modest amount removed around the mounting bracket for the Runcam. Either way, 3 printing filament flexes much more easily than carbon and I did want it to wedge in there a little bit.

If anyone out there has a REAL Alien and isn't a despicable human being like me (for having purchased a $17 clone) I'd love to know if it fits the real Alien.

comments.text: I printed this in PLA+ for the real 5" alien and it fit great.  I'm using a Foxeer Arrow 3 and as you stated the alignment isn't perfect but it's close enough to work fine.  That .01mm or whatever it is doesn't matter.  I've broken a few carbon camera plates and am sick of using those camera back additions for mounting.  I'll let you know how it holds up.  I'm pretty rusty so I'm sure it will get a good thrashing soon.
comments.author: mkmitchell

comments.text:
Nice! thanks for letting me know! hope it works well for you.
Yeah, I suspected this clone was a very very close approximation in terms of measurements - quality-wise ... it's horrendous :)
comments.author: mkmitchell

comments.text: Nice! I'd be interested to see how this holds up in a crash. It should be okay, but I'm always wary of rigid printed parts on a quad.
comments.author: hackentosher

comments.text: I'm pretty curious as well. Honestly though - I printed this in nylon. I think a far greater concern is creating enough force to simply bend the mount out of place and eject it.... Taulman 910 in this thickness is pretty hard to break as it flexes a bit.  In PETG I'd be more worried about cracking.  You wouldn't think it but the forces associated with a crash on a cam are crazy... I used to bend the metal mount for my foxeer all the time...
comments.author: hackentosher

description.text:
This is a stand for the Feather model AS-D2 shaving razor. For razors with a larger diameter handle, you will need to enlarge the hole. The stand is in two parts so that it can be filled with steel shot or ball bearings,

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XR2GN2G/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

to give it stability and heft. I chose to embed the weights in epoxy, so they wouldn't rattle, and put self-adhesive rubber on the bottom. Then, I sanded and painted mine with stainless steel paint.

author: RobinsBlog_de

print_settings.Notes::
The low gain antennae. these are just too thin to print, I suggest you use four bits of wire.
The model of Lunokhod as a whole, this is just to give you a guide as to how it should look.
The lid, which is best printed as two halves, on their sides and glued together.

description.text:
FULL DETAILS AT MY WEBSITE WWW.STUBMANDREL.CO.UK

Lunokhod 1 and 2 were a pair of exceptionally successful robotic moon rovers that the Soviet Union sent to the moon in 1970 and 1973. Owing to the politics of the time this remarkable achievement went largely unnoticed in the west.

The eight-wheeled rovers were about the size of a small car, and in fact they were intended to act as safety/escape vehicles to support manned lunar expeditions.

Lunokhod '0' was destroyed when its launch vehicle exploded in 1969, but Lunokhod's 1 and 2 were successful. Lunokhod 3 was never launched and is on display in the Lavochin Museum.

I had a fascination with the Lunokhod program as a youngster, fuelled by the almost complete lack of information about the missions. When I got a 3D printer I discovered that no-one appears to have made one before, although there are some excellent conventional models. So I put that right and made my own Lunokhod 1.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.14mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I hate the poor quality STLs on many 3D sharing sites that are impossible to print. All of the STLs in this zip folder have been printed at actual size (dimensions in millimetres) WITHOUT SUPPORTS. That said, many of the parts are not in an optimal orientation for printing and will need to be arranged to suit your printer.

The exceptions are:

The low gain antennae. these are just too thin to print, I suggest you use four bits of wire.
The model of Lunokhod as a whole, this is just to give you a guide as to how it should look.
The lid, which is best printed as two halves, on their sides and glued together.

You WILL need to be careful and creative in the use of cyanoacrylate glue to put everything together. I have NOT included assembly instructions, reference to Vincent Meen's drawings, photos of Lunokhod 3 and the STL of the assembled Lunokhod should be enough to guide you in assembling the model.

My model is based on the exceptionally useful plans at spacemodels.net and I fully acknowledge Vincent Meens as my main source for dimensional and constructional information on the Lunokhod. That said, the pdf files on his website were unsuitable for making a 3D digital model, so I redrew the rover entirely in TurboCAD from scratch. I have modelled Lunokhod 1, as I was becoming stir crazy and did not have the patience to add all of the extra accessories for Lunokhod 2.

title: Prusa i3 screw down vibration damper feet

description.text:
This is a couple of vibration dampening feet printed in flex material that hold the m10 rods on the prusa i3 design to keep the printer off the ground and dampen vibrations. They are designed to be screwed down into the surface below the printer.

I made these because I got tired of always carefully placing my dampers whenever I had to move the printer. With these the printer is always placed in the same perfect position in my enclosure.

Printer Brand:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

No

0.2

15% fast honeycomb

Notes:

Printed in generic TPU/flex material. I follow Makers Muse YouTube tutorial for successful flex prints on the Prusa i3 mk2.

I made sure the center of the honeycomb infill was in the center of the model to create an even stiffness in both the x and y axis, see picture.

author: hallonhatt

description.text:
These are three houses modeled after houses in the Drassen Airport level of the Jagged Alliance 2 video game. The houses are modeled in a scale of 1 square = 20mm, which should be about 1/50, close to 28mm wargaming scale. Rescale as desired for other scales.

You can print the houses (except the roof) in one piece, but in my experience print quality is much better when the various parts are printed lying down flat and assembled afterwards. This can be achieved by setting the offset variable in the OpenSCAD files to a value larger than 0, exporting the STL, importing in your slicer software, and then split the file (at least that's how it is done in Slic3r) and rotate the parts to your liking. I have included exploded files for all houses and the roof. Rotate the roof parts by 20 degrees (the roof angle) to have them lay flat.

The designs are not fully parametric, some dimensions are hardcoded. Modification shouldn't be too difficult.

description.text:
This door bell enclosure houses a 1602 LCD with a 16mm push button which are connected to an Arduino along with a piezo buzzer.

Code can be found on my GitHub: https://github.com/hiruna/Simple-Arduino-Door-Bell

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.28mm or 0.12mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

  • Print the front of the enclosure (exposed to outside) facing down. [See Simplify3D screenshot]

  • Only use supports for the overhang where the wall mounting holes are.

• Depending on the how the supports printed around the overhang, you may need to file it lightly.

  • If the wall mounting holes are small, use a round precision file to make it bigger.
I took the rough measurements of where the old intercom was mounted and designed this enclosure to fit a 1602 LCD and a 16mm push button. I used Fusion 360 to design the model.

title: RS-8: Motorized Airplane
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An airplane of about 50g weight with a wing span of 44,2cm and 20mm * 8mm motor with 3d printed parts, balsa wood and tissue covering the wing. It uses inexpensive motor and battery from common quadcopter repair packs resulting in a cost in parts of well below 10 Euro per plane.

We had 9 eight year old kids successfully build this plane with massive support of grown-ups. Due to shorter axes of some motors not all of them flew right away, but this issue was fixed with this improved model and all of them got their own plane.

So far, the plane design survived many grass landings but it will break printed parts and sometimes the propeller when landing on hard floor such as concrete. (Update 6.8.17: After stalling from well over 5m height, the motor body once even broke on grass, replacement is in print.)

The length of flight heavily depends on tuning, weight and improvements to the design.

Please consider using safety googles due to the extremely fast spinning motor.

Update 6.8.17: Fixed scaling of motor part and PLA wire length.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

I was using 1,75mm PLA and successfully printed with and without support. In doubt, try using support first. The print tends to be cleaner without support.

In my case, I had to print the motor body part at 105%, or else inserting the motor would break the part. The STL with all parts has this part scaled to 105%, the single STL file is at 100%, so you can try your luck.

The design of the wing is based on Ultralight RC Glider From Scrap (licensed CC BY-NC-SA at time of download) by charlieCG.

All parameters were determined by Modellberechnung-V01 by Christian Forrer.

The airplane is built from 3D printed parts, balsa wood and other parts. There are some links to amazon for the parts.

3D printed

  • wing body
  • 8 wing supports
  • 2 wing tips
  • motor body
  • tail

Balsa Wood

  • 2 wing bar 20,8 cm x 0,5 cm x 0,5 cm
  • fuselage bar 22 cm x 0,5 cm x 0,5 cm
    balsa wood 5 mm x 5 mm x 1000 mm
  • wing tail 42,6 cm x 1 cm x 0,1 cm
    balsa wood 1 mm x 100 mm x 1000 mm

Others

  • motor 3,7 V , 2,0 cm length, 0,8 cm diameter
    replacement motor for H107C H107D quadcopter, attach connector pins
    4 motors with propellers, 6 motors w/o propellers
  • propeller
    16 propeller blades
  • 3,7V 150 mAh LiPo
    6 LiPo 3,7V 150mAh with USB charger, 6 LiPo 3,7V 150mAh with USB charger
  • 45,4 cm filament with 1,75 mm diameter for the front of the wing
  • rubber band
  • tissue ("Japanese napkin" / "Japan-Servietten")
  • glue
    glue for structure, glue for tissue

And in case you do not have some: 12 safety goggles.

Step 1: Start with the wing body and wing tips and connect them with the two 20,8cm balsa bars Step 2: Glue the 42,6cm wing tail onto the wing body and tips with strong glue and some pressure. Step 3: Pull the 45,4cm long 1,75mm filament trough the wing body and stick it into the wing tips. Step 4: Place the wing supports onto the center bar but below the wing tail with an exact distance of 4cm between each support. Align the filament wire to the support. Starting from the center, use a drop of strong glue to fix the wire to the support in a straight position. Then, again starting from the center, use the glue to fix the support to the wing tail with some pressure. Step 5: Unfold the napkin or tissue and separate its parts. Cut it in half create two straight edges for the center and the back side. Do this for the left and right side of the upper side of the wing. Step 6: Apply paper glue lightly onto the wing and put the tissue on it. Pull it straight without tearing it apart. Step 7: Wait for the glue to dry. Step 8: Cut the overlapping tissue. You might want to save the tissue for repairs, in case the surface breaks after some flights. Step 9: Turn the wing around and redo steps 5-8. Step 10: Carefully place the motor into the motor body. Do some sanding or cutting until it fits, or your body will break. It is advisable to solder some pins onto the motor wires. Put the battery in, depending on the exact size, you might have to turn it around to stick it in. Test the polarization and turning direction of the propellor. Switch the polarization until the propeller blows the wind backwards. Safety google are advisable. Step 11: Put the tail onto the fuselage bar. Step 12: Carefully attach the wing onto the fuselage bar using the rubber band. Step 13: Turn the wing around and carefully insert the fuselage bar into the motor body part. Lift the rubber band on the one side and the wing on the other side onto the motor body part. Step 14: Push the fuselage bar into the motor body part until it is flush with the battery holder. Position the wing until the back part to the body part is approximately at the center of gravity. Step 15: Have a flight over grass by throwing the plane into free air space!

Try modifying the wing position, and try bending the tail flaps. Share your experiences and improve the design!

description.text:
This is a travel case for the Feather Model AS-D2 safety razor, a 5-pack of blades, and a small pair of tweezers. It can be readily adapted to razors of other sizes. The print is in three parts: the case top and bottom and the latch. I used cut-down brass escutcheon pins for the hinge pins, but any appropriate diameter wire will do.

I put in the hinge pins, then sanded the case exterior while it was closed. Of course, you don't have to sand it if you prefer. The case was printed in colorFabb nGen and the latch was printed in Taulman PCTPE. The latch was clamped in place and glued with Cyberbond 2002, a wicking-type cyanoacrylate:

http://www.audiologysupplies.com/ecom/productpage/a6af12b8-95d5-41ff-b64c-8e5eaa31c8ca?category=daeb57df-9915-478d-ac89-d8cd731951b7

100%

This is my take on a useful tool.

It cuts 1.75mm filament in a 45° angle for a better grip when inserting it into the feeder gear.

• No screws are needed.

Prints without support.
The printer should be well calibrated before attempting this print, since it needes fine detail to work.

Additional Needed Parts:
1x Spring out of a pen

title: Parametric dial gauge holder for Replicator

description.text:
This is basically a remake of phineasjw's Replicator Bed Level Jig in OpenSCAD. It's not as fancy, because my patience with OpenSCAD ran out, but it does work.
My dial gauge was too short for the original. With this one you can make a custom jig that suits your dial gauge diameter and length. You can also customise holes for the magnets.

The variable dial_gauge_z sets the distance between the top of the milled rods, to the top of the beam where the dial gauge rests. The attached STL is at 15mm. If you go much lower, you may need to play around with the filleting. For printing and usage, see the excellent instructions at
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23257

I wanted a way to carry my Glock 23 when driving but still have quick access should the need arise. This console holster fits horizontally inside the console with grip pointed toward the driver. Thanks to PrintedFirearm for the basic holster shape, this is a remix.

To adhere you can cut the thin piece of carpet at the bottom of the console to match the profile, then use double stick tape or glue to attach to the plastic console bottom. I'll upload additional designs with a longer base to wedge fit, but wanted to upload the original design for people that have different size consoles.

Printed with PetG, as I've had issues with PLA melting inside the console in the Texas heat.

Look here for additional (and soon to be revised) console trays, as well as other Tacoma and truck parts:

  • Console Trays https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2260403
  • CargoTie Downs https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2289782

Update 8/5/2017

  • v2 has about 10mm extra length for the gun barrel.
  • *short has been shortened and should fit the Glock 23 exactly.
  • *cmd_holster is a through-design that uses 3M Command Adhesive strips to attach the holster to the inside front of the console without having a base. I recommend using the heavy duty Command Strips for this.

Update 8/6/2017

    • v2_mag adds a magazine holder on the side. I have not test printed this one., but I liked Glocky's make and remix so I made a version that will also hold a magazine. (itself a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22665)

Update 8/7/2017

    • screw_holster is a mod of the Cmd Strip without the base. I've added screw holes in case you wish to permanently attach it to your console, desk, or whatever.

description.text:
USE TWO SHELLS ONLY ON TOLERANCE BOARD -

With 0.4mm nozzle or above it will be similar to 100% infill and have slightly different results, print 100% infill later to compare results ####

Objects are designed to test the margins/tolerances of your 3D printer.
By knowing the tolerances your printer creates with, you can make adjustments int he model and get near perfect results.

Tolerance objects are small so they are quick to print and exist around the 5mm mark for checking (4.8 - 5.3 mm). Holes with consisting pins consist of Semi Circle, Square, Circle and Hex (for allen keys).

Print the tolerance board, to check tolerance of holes;

  • use vernier calipers to check the sizes of holes
  • use real time objects to see how they fit
  • print the 'pins' which fit the holes to see which one fits

Choose a set of 'pins' with handles for easy manipulation ;
"Tolerances-All_4_8.stl" - has pins of 4.8mm
"Tolerances-All_4_9.stl" - has pins of 4.9mm
"Tolerances-All_5_0.stl" - has pins of 5.0mm...
..."Tolerances-All_5_3.stl" - has pins of 5.3mm

Discover tolerances between Prints and real world objects and between two separate prints. This will allow for easy designing of functioning parts int he future.

description.text:
This little elephant is based off of a Danish modern stone elephant sculpture I purchased at a vintage modern boutique. The original design (second photo) was carved around the 1950's and it's being brought back to life today through 3D printing!

It's a very straightforward print and looks great in a multitude of colors, though our favorite is with marble style filament or flex filament! You can print one yourself or visit our Etsy store to get one from us!

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 E3D V6 Direct Mount

description.text:
This is a X-Carriage for E3D V6 hot end using the extruder parts from Anet A8 (or similar common designs). I made this for my P3Steel, CartesianOne and AM8 frames and it is easy to print with very little or no clean up required. This is a robust direct drive solution with good access for maintenance and a very short filament path. You can use some nice part cooling fan designs made for the Anet A8 (like the Mistral) with this design.

You can choose between 2 (E3d_mount_v4.5.stl) or 3 (E3D_V6_3_block_v2.stl) bearing block designs. I prefer the 2 block bearing design, but the 3 block version is a quick upgrade/change with less risk of breaking anything during disassembly/reassembly of your kit printer. The bearing blocks could be taken from your existing printer or you can use some lightweight version like the one in the photos. It should be easy to avoid any binding with the smooth rods and there is also some room to adjust the M4 screws. (I finally got to use my Drylin Igus bearing with this carriage).
Fasten the x-carriage to the bearing blocks before adding the stepper motor. Attach the stepper motor with one short M3 screw and then add the extruder part from your A8. (you will probably need longer screws, and please get some with hex sockets). Use a PTFE tube from inside the hotend and up as close as possible to the gear, without the tube touching it. On my printer I ended up with a 52,3 mm long PTFE tube (with an original E3D V6)

On some of the photos you can see a cable relief clamp, I decided to remove that and have provided two slanted cut outs for zip cable ties below the stepper motor (see last photo). Use those to secure the cables from your hotend, thermistor and steppermotor. This is important as the heater cartridge and heatblock can fall off and possibly start a fire.

I recommend using screws with hex heads as access is limited to some parts and a allen key is better than a long screwdriver for some of this work.

I have provided some photos in sequence (at the end of all the photos) to show how to assemble this. Please let me know if anything needs to be improved or clarified. The sample prints are made in PLA (PolyMax) and the one with yellow background and outdoors in PETG (3DNET).

Video showing the x-carriage in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JlBxuBOYW8Y

Update 05.01.2018
Uploaded new and "cleaner" versions with some cosmetic changes and improvements. On the 3 bearing block version the lower blocks can now be adjusted even more than before. Please note that all the photos and the video show the old versions.
I have also uploaded a wheelbased-version for use with 2020 extrusion. Download and print two standard spacers and one adjustable spacer. You need three mini wheel kits and 3 sets M5 bolts, nuts and washers.

Update 10. March 2018
Uploaded belt attachment blocks for the wheelbased version of the carriage.

comments.text:
I wonder if there would/could be an advantage in using a geared extruder and a smaller extruder stepper ?
The Pitan extruder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2728600) seems quite easy to print, an E3Dv6 can be mounted directly in it (as with the Titan) - you just need the right "bracket" on the carriage in order to be able to mount the extruder and motor (the mirrored version would probably be needed for this type of carriage)..
Maybe a new project/remix ? ;-)
comments.author: bipsen

comments.text: I did publish a carriage for the E3D Titan for use with a small (original) pancake stepper but I wasn't happy with it so I deleted the design from Thingiverse. I never got the Titan to work properly. (periodically skipping steps and generally not getting the results I wanted). The Titan extruder and stepper sits on a shelf now collecting dust. Maybe some day I will look into it again.

comments.text: Hi, I'm very curious about this upgrade. May I ask you some questions? Have you noticed any print quality improvement compared to stock hot end? What are the another advantages? Thank you for your time and attention!
comments.author: gui_bera

comments.text: The main advantages: Easier access to the filament path makes changing filament much easier (you can actually see what you are doing). You can also use an all metal hotend and print at higher temperatures. There is a large number of E3D original and clone hot end parts parts that will work with this setup.

comments.author: bipsen

comments.text: I have used the original E3D V6 direct drive version and a Chinese E3d V6 clone. The original is using a collar to keep the short teflon tube in place. I am not using a teflon tube with the Chinese clone and it works fine on ABS, PETG and PLA. I would expect flexible filaments to work only with the teflon tube in place.

This is an Anemometer for Arduino. The bottom and the top part come together with an ball-bearing. In the bottom part is a reed contact and a magnet is in the top part. With an Arduino you can measure the time between two peaks from the reed contact. With this information you can measure the wind speed.

ATTENTION: BEFORE PRINTING YOU HAVE TO SCALE THIS OBJECT WITH THE FACTOR 10 !
(I have a problem with the settings in my CAD Program)

I also added the Inventor Files, if you want to make a remix or something else.

You can see the full anemometer here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VI9HWjiexwA

author: andygock

title: Wall mount for Maglite D series

description.text:
When I stumbled upon my Maglite 3D this morning, I decided that it might be a good idea to mount it somewhere where I could find it easily on power outages.

So I designed a small wall mount and used it to mount it on the door of the wall cupboard also containing our fuse boxes.

This is a first shot. I printed it using white ABS but it should also come out smoothly using PLA. I actually printed it with the mount side flat on the printbed and added some support for the top of the rings.

While the outcome is relatively stable, it might be a good idea to improve the print by connecting the rings on both sides (if you plan a mod/remake).

description.text:
The pod deck is to fit inside the wonderful model Discovery from 2001 (XD-1).

This is a modelling project combining 3d printed parts and leds with a PIR.

Printer:

creality3d cr 10 3d

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

fine

where needed 15%

Notes:

I used pla nozzle temp 210 and a bed temp 50
The size of my bits are to fit 1.3 the size of XD-1 which makes the overall size 5FT. The front dome is sliced and the rear part assembled with the collar the pod bay is a free 3dmax file I modified.Cutting the plastic with a vibrating multi tool is straight forward. The pod door is drilled all round the outside with a small drill and popped out. The observation deck is cut away and the glazing bars are replaced by a small piece of .175 filament the a piece of milk bottle plastic put in for glass a small soldering iron is a useful tool for this.

Bowman looking out is any small figure printed and stuck in place with the iron. A spray of paint on the inside stops light from leds coming thought hull. The spacesuits are the same figure. The claw on the pod are chunky but at the right size it works great there are some great pod models on thingiverse to stick them onto again the iron is the tool, printing the pod hollow an fitting the led's is a fiddle.

Leds

There are three leds on the observation deck and 4 on the pod deck and 4 in the pod a pir switches it on and off it works with my brackets.

using 123d and free 3dmax files

I am learning, my modelling skills are better than 3d designing

remixed_from.author: CallJoe
remixed_from.title: Creality CR-10 Dial Indicator Mount for Bed Level/Tramming

title: CR-10 DTI  holder for bed alignment

description.text:
To make bed leveling quick and accurate I printed a holder for this very cheap but excellent quality DTI.
Link to the DTI which the bracket fits. https://goo.gl/9HYmRr
The DTI is fitted to the holder and pushed on the the fan housing. The code is selected from the SD card and it will first heat up the bed and nozzle to operating temperature (if required) and then home the bed and pause whilst the height is set with a slip of paper between bed and nozzle.
After a delay the Z axis rises and then descends onto the bed and the DTI is set to zero.
After a pause it then moves to each corner in turn and the bed adjusting screw is turned until the DTI reads zero.
It then returns to to the home position, rises and the DTI can be removed ready to print.
I have printed these leveling knob attachments and they make adjustment very easy, no more fumbling around under the bed.
The gcode is here
http://myfordboy.blogspot.co.uk/p/creality-cr-10.html

UPDATE
I have uploaded another file with the DTI holder further forward to suit other model.

Printer:

cr10

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used 100% infill for strength but I am sure less would work.

comments.text: Works perfect for the new CR-10S 2018
comments.author: Raphnix

comments.text:
Nice design, but I had quite a few adventures getting one printed...
First one came out warped in all dimensions : funny to have bed alignment issues while printing a gadget for better bed alignment :-)
Next one was OK, but it felt slightly "shrunk" somehow, it wouln't fit on the print head. I had to sand it lightly on the inside with a Dremel, and also widen the bore of the DTI holder with an 8mm drill bit (I broke the warped one trying to push it in).
Maybe my Cura parameters were wrong ?
I also had a big surprise : all versions printed without a support ! It just built the sides and then added the holder support across the void :-)
I thought this kind of thing was supposed to be impossible ?....
Lastly, I hadn't seen the last comment and had the same problem with the DTI ordered through your link, the body was too thick : for now I just removed the plastic back plate and it fits just fine, but I need to try the new version :-)
Many thanks for this anyway !
comments.author: fpp

Can you upload a version with the hole shifted away from the frame about 3mm please? title: Draw and Drill a MCP3008 circuit board

description.text:
This is an example of what can be done with my experiment PCB Prusa Factory ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415508)

1) What is this board ?
It is a Analog Voltage reader with 8 channels based on MCP3008 chip in SOIC format.

It provides an easy way to connect 8 Analog Sensors, for each channel, 3 pins are designed to host 3pin dupont cables.
These dupont cable are used to connect to the analog device, and provide : Ground, , Maximum voltage ( VREF) and the MCP3008 pin.

There are 2 switches SW1 and SW2 which allows to decide to use the same 3,3V for digital voltage and for the VREF of sensors.

Putting the SW1 and SW2 switches will use the 3.3V from the digital V to be sent to the sensors.

if you want to use 5V sensors, do not put the SW1 and SW2 switches , and connect the Analog Voltage 5V to VREF, and Analog Ground to AGND.

There are 4 pins to allow connection to a raspberry pi or arduino, using a 4 pins dupont cable.

2) Want to try to make this PCB with your printer ?

2.0 build the Tools to allow your printer to handle a pen and a drill motor with a drill bit.
check my PrusaPCBFactory objects ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415508 )
and download the tool holders, so that it is easy to fix Tools to your printer without impatcing the printing feature. ( some design may be needed if you are not using a prusa emotiontech printer. )

2.1 print the 3DPrint__Support-STD.gcode support file.
this will print the support for the PCB. This support needs to remain in place on the bed of the printer, do not remove the support from the printer bed.
Add some scotch to the support to ensure that it will not move at all.

2.2 Mount the pen tool and calibrate
Launch the auto home feature. Normally, after autohome, the tool holder is outside of the printer bed, and it is then possible to mount a tool on the tool holder.
Mount the pen tool on your printer ( if you used my holders, the pen tool simply slides on the tool holder).
Use the move commands from the panel to move the tool to the edge of the Arrow of the support.The pen must touch precisely the edge of the Arrow.
Note x,y,z values from the printer panel.

Edit the Pen__coppertop+_copper.gcode file with a text editor ( Notepad.exe)
search between the lines ;CALIBRATION_START and ;CALIBRATION_END
Modify the 3 lines G92 with the x,y,z values that you noted previously
G92 X-46
G92 Y-53.4
G92 Z-21.8
be sure to leave the minus character : "G92 X-" and add the value after.

Save the GCODE file.

2.3 cut a Copper clad with following size :
Width :36,592002
Height :32,512
and install it on the support. Be carefull not to move the support !

2.4 launch the modified gcode file on the printer
Verify that the etch resist pen ( staedtler pen, nothing else ! ) moves correctly to draw the PCB. I recommend that you first test the gcode without the pen, to see how the printer moves, and verify that it looks ok.
then check that the printer is drawing correctly the pcb on the copper.

2.5 etch the copper clad with etchant.

2.6 put the copper clad on the support

2.7 mount the Motor drill and calibrate motor drill, by puting the drill bit at the edge of the Arrow, noting x,y,z and updating the drill gcode file with the values

2.8 launch the drill gcode in test mode
do not turn on the drill motor, and ensure that the drill motor can move freely on Z axis.

then launch the drill gcode, and verify that the drill bit touches exactly where the holes should be.
recalibrate if needed.
then , fix the drill motor on z axis, and launch definitively the drill gcode file.
this will drill each hole.

author: francfalco

description.text:
If you own a shade or awning or curtain controlled by a Somfy remote control, and would like to control it from anywhere in the world. This is the gadget for you.

It is a simple box with a servo that pushes the buttons. In my case it controls shades in my house. The heart is an Adafruit HAZZAH ESP8266 breakout board. https://www.adafruit.com/product/2471
This board allows you to use a web browser to control it.

The "pusher" is glued using 5 minute epoxy to the servo horn. It is powered with a 5 volt wall wart. The clip is used to hold the servo in. I use a clip because the servo needs to come out in order to put the "Somfy remote" into the unit. The HAZZAH is fastened to the box using double sided sticky tape.

Once built and running you will have to determine the ip address of the HAZZAH and then use a web browser to get the web page designed into it. This lets you test it by turning an LED on and off. If you want to use the unit outside of your local area. You will have to do port forwarding on your wireless router. I did the port forwarding and I am able to raise and lower my shades from anywhere in the world.

I have been using this for 3 weeks now and it has been working flawlessly.

Designed with Freecad

Thanks you Freecad !

comments.text: This is nice!
