author: CyberJack

print_settings.Notes:: Recommend printing with opaque white filament, as seen in JPG image files

description.text:
Longer pinhole solar eclipse viewer, assembled from 2 identical pieces (so that longer viewer can be printed on small print bed), based on previous version at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463404.

SCAD and STL files included. SCAD file shows only one piece, STL file has 2 identical pieces to print together.

See post-print instructions -- some assembly required.

To use viewer: Point viewer with hole (poked or drilled post-print) toward sun and line up the bright dot (image of the sun) on the flat surface at the other end. During the partial phase of a solar eclipse, the dot will be party obscured by the moon, creating a crescent shape instead of a round dot. If you are fortunate enough to be viewing the eclipse within the path of totality, when the eclipse is total, you should even see a faint image of the sun's corona.

JPG image files show separate pieces, hole in one piece, assembled viewer, and viewer in use with late morning full sun (several weeks before 2017 eclipse).

See http://www.eclipse2017.org

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Sliced using Cura

The supports are important, pieces in STL file are arranged to minimize the supports, but without them the overhang of the glue tabs won't print correctly.

Recommend printing with opaque white filament, as seen in JPG image files

1. Poke (using sturdy thumbtack or small nail) or drill a small circular hole (no more than 1/16in or 1.5mm) at the center of the cross in one printed piece -- in my assembled viewer shown in images, I started by poking a hole with a thumbtack, then widened the hole a bit with a very small drill bit, twisting it by hand rather than using a drill
  2. Glue the pieces together as shown in image, using glue tabs -- I used a consumer cyanoacrylate, holding the pieces together with small locking pliers while the glue set; the glue doesn't need to be that strong, though, something like silicone cement should work fine

To use viewer: Point viewer with hole end toward sun and line up the bright dot (image of the sun) on the flat surface at the other end. During the partial phase of a solar eclipse, the dot will be party obscured by the moon, creating a crescent shape instead of a round dot. If you are fortunate enough to be viewing the eclipse within the path of totality, when the eclipse is total, you should even see a faint image of the sun's corona.

comments.text: So cool that you came up with this design - hopefully will be easier than building a bunch of pin-hole-viewing-boxes out of what ever components I can dig up will be.  Will print and test it out tomorrow (sunny weather permitting).

title: Tire tread for Arduino Self balancing robot

description.text:
This is a tire tread for the "Remotely controlled - Arduino Self balancing robot"
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2306541

It has to be printed with Flex filament to work. It will wrap around the wheel and make it wider so it fits very well. The stretch of the flex filament should overcome any printer miss calibration.

It is not as grippy(sticky) as I would like on a smooth surface, it might slip. On any soft surface it should be fine. You might be better off with the bike innertube band but feel free to give it a try.

Even if you don't build the robot as designed it is a great platform for doing your own thing...

I designed these paddle clippers for my Fusion 124 kayak. They are for a 30 mm diameter paddle, and they use M5 machine screws and bolts.

These paddle clippers will only work with Fusion 124 kayaks since it's designed with its angles in consideration.
You can add adhesive foam to the insides.

These are 3D models for some knobs for Heathkit equipment.

For the latest versions see: https://github.com/jefftranter/3dmodels/tree/master/HeathkitKnobs

knob-medium: Medium sized knob used on test equipment and radios like the Heathkit HR-10B.

knob-large: Large sized knob used on test equipment and radios like the Heathkit HR-10B.

knob-small: Small sized knob used on test equipment and radios like the Heathkit HR-10B.

pointer: White pointer that is mounted under the large knob on some models.

knob-medium-concentric: Medium sized knob designed to have the small knob mounted concentric to it. The center knob is usually coloured red.

The .scad files are the original OpenSCAD files that were created by hand. The .stl files were generated from OpenSCAD and are suitable for loading into your 3D printer/slicer software, such as Cura.

They are intended to be printed using a 3D printer. I have had good results with these using LulzBot Mini and Prusa i3 printers. Use the highest quality, but don't expect the quality to be the same as the original knobs.

You should print these using support material. After printing, remove the support material. I used 20% infill. You may want to use 100% on the small knob. You may need to file the hole for the shaft slightly to get it to fit. An 8-32 set screw (6-32 for the small knob) of suitable length is needed to tighten the knob on the shaft. For the knobs that have pointers, you can apply some white paint on the pointer.

I used PLA material. You can experiment with other materials. ABS, for example, could potentially be treated with acetone to make the knobs smoother.

This is just me turning Mjolnir (based on the movie design) into a pencil and dice case for gaming, complete with a dice tower on the top third (or so) of the hammer head. The handle has additional pencil space. The only thing not 3D printed on this is I used two 1 1/4" x 17 wire brad "finishing nails" as the cotter pins for the hinges. I also could have printed it out of gray filament, but I didn't have any, thus the gray primer. I'd love to see other prints of this!

BTW, the files were originally printed on a Creality CR-10. A smaller printer might need to have the pieces chopped up a bit, the hammer heads are 8" long, and the handle is 7 1/2" long.

title: Model Rocket Display Bases
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In my vast collection of model rockets, I have several that cannot stand on their own three/four fins due to protrusions that extend below said fins. For some, I have created wall mounts out of PVC pipe and fittings to give the illusion of flying, which works great for those, but others - the smaller models, do not lend themselves well to that method. For those, I have designed these little display stands. I will add more designs, as well as photos of the completed stands, as time allows.

base1 and base1b are designed to display rockets that use Estes A sized engines.
base2 is designed to display certain older water/air powered rockets

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

For Estes A sized engine models (including the 1/4 and 1/2 A sizes) scale base1 up 112% for proper fit.

The opening in base2 is ~13.5mm in diameter. Scale the entire model up or down to suit your needs.

Be kind with your comments. My computer did not have enough power to handle this model in Sketchup - my go to design program with which I am well familiar - so I decided to finally give FreeCAD and Blender a try. I designed the first one - base1 - in FreeCAD in the Parts workbench; converted it to a mesh; exported that; and ran it through NetFabb. I wanted to try my hand at creating valleys in the exhaust flame, so I loaded that STL into Blender and played around with it a bit there. I know it's not perfect, but I'm learning and I think it's pretty good for my maiden attempt.

title: Arcadia Quest Inferno Fountain for FDM Printers

description.text:
A friend of mine asked if I could print him the Arcadia Quest Inferno Fountain by YAAARGH, but the model is very clearly intended for resin printers and would have been exceedingly difficult to produce on my FDM machine. I took the liberty of slicing the model up into multiple flat-planed surfaces so that my printer could actually handle it without a silly amount of support usage. I straightened out the tail, too, so it could be printed flat. Not as perfect as resin might be, but still pretty good!

Please note that the model photos are just loosely stuck together. The seams on places like the shoulder shouldn't be an issue once you glue everything up.

title: DJI Mavic Pro - Spring Loaded Tablet Holder (Portable version)

description.text:
Slightly more portable version of another tablet holder I already have on Thingiverse,
this version has more universal holding tabs to secure different types of tablets,
also I added the holes on the main base so you can grip the RC controller a little more securely a quick release holder and a two piece base for complete breakdown for transporting.

Use a 1/4 x 20 x 1 1/2 in socket head bolt and a 1/4 x 20 nut for the knob.

The print orientation is the same as the pictures.

The spring is a 3" tension type spring, that can be easily adjusted by stretching it, if needed,
the spring mounts between the two holes using whatever you want to use, I used some rivets I had lying around, trim as needed, I also used some CA on the pin to keep it from falling out.

title: Thermoworks Smoke Receiver Armored Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an armored cover for the receiver of the Thermoworks Smoke remote thermometer system. After my first use I found I was getting BBQ fingerprints on my receiver, and it was a bit smooth, making it hard to hold onto with oily / wet / greasy hands. Also if I had the receiver around my neck, I was banging the receiver against things when bending down etc. So for fun I thought I would try creating a cover for it. It worked out pretty well, however my first version did not have a hole in the back. Which made it very hard to remove when using the Sainsmart Semiflex TPU. So I designed a second version with a hole in the back, so that you can press the receiver out more easily. This was much easier to remove.

There are three files included:
1- Standard version, smooth bottom, without a finger hole.
2- Standard version, smooth bottom, with a finger hole in the back.
3- Hexagonal pattern on the bottom, with a finger hole in the back.

I have not tried with a more flexible filament yet, so something like ninjaflex or other very soft filament may not require a finger hole in the back. I do not recommend printing this with standard filaments. The fit is very tight, and you may not get the receiver back out without breaking the case.

author: Merlin1974

description.text: Holds Printed and Real Teeth around 4" and bigger, without a need to scale. The printed example above is this one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1380493

I really wanted LED lighting on my Monoprice Maker Select V2. I use Octoprint (Octopi) to control my printer and have found the timelapse feature valuable not only for entertainment purposes, but also as a troubleshooting tool when things go awry. The problem on long prints is that I have to leave the lights on at night to get a good exposure.

I've tried just placing LED strips on the frame, but they cast too many shadows and the print head is really in the way. I have my (PS3) camera mounted to a the front of the bed on a modified version of a mount I found here (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1554572) and wanted light coming from the same direction and above the bed.

The perfect solution was to put the LED strips on the Z-axis threaded rod I added as my first mod. The only issue was holding the LEDs in place and preventing glare back to the camera (and the viewer).

So I came up with these two mounts that make little "reflectors" for your standard 12V adhesive LED strips. Each mount holds 9 LEDs (3 3-LED sections) and provides plenty of light.

I made the clip on design first, but printed in PLA the "clips" tend to crack as the material doesn't flex enough to clip on and hold without cracking. You may get better results with PETG or other materials that are a little less brittle, but I went ahead and designed a version that uses small zip ties and that works great and gives a clean enough install for me.

To drive the LEDs I went into the control box and tapped 12V from the PSU. I am using a sainsmart 2-relay module (only using one right now, may add power control from Octoprint) that I got on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0057OC6D8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

To control the lights, I began using this excellent tutorial here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1428478 but was never able to quite get the bash scripts to work inside of Octoprint (permissions issues I believe, and I found another solution before I solved that issue). But this tutorial was instrumental in helping me get into the project and understand what needed to be done.

My final solution was to use LED Strip Control plugin for Octoprint (https://github.com/google/OctoPrint-LEDStripControl) which is designed to control RGB LEDs, but can be used very simply to trigger an on-off command. Just use the Red channel control and set it up in the plugin to talk to whatever GPIO pin you choose for triggering the relay.

So with the relay trigger plugged into my RPi (3) physical pin 12 (GPIO 18) and the relay powered with 12V from the PSU, issuing an M150 GCODE command turns on my LEDs and M150 R255 turns them off. I realize this is backwards, but I wired my relay backwards in my final assembly (I also added a hot bed MOSFET and the recommended grounding mods to the Melzi board - wow are my temps rock solid!) and didn't want to open the control box to reverse it.

In practice I added the on and off commands to my default pre- and post- GCODE in my slicer (Cura) and in Octoprint, I added the following to ~/.octoprint/config.yaml:

controls:
- children:
  - command: M150
    name: Lights On
  - command: M150 R255
    name: Lights Off
  layout: horizontal
  name: Lights

This gives me an "On" and "Off" button on my Controls tab in Octoprint.

Note that I printed this face down with and without support from the bed. If your bridging is good you should have success, and I did on my first tests but I preferred to print with support from the build plate as the inside surface was more consistent for adhering the LED strips. The support comes out easily and leaves a more uniform finish.

I included the step files incase you want to make shorter or longer (although this was the max for my bed, given that you have to cut the LED strips at 3 LED intervals).

title: LWC Airsoft "R.C.M" Remote claymore  mine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The R.C.M is the Big brother of the PC, not only does it pack a much lager punch but also it can be remote controlled up to 100meters!!!!
There are just a few coponents you will need additionaly and its pretty simple to build.
Only downside, you need a printer wo is able to print that big.

To sum up the remote mine you will definitely need a fitting remote controller housing, check it out right here at fateros Thingiverse page: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686701

The servo needs some work to make it possible to directly using it without a controller, Check out the following very helpful video I found on Youtube, watch it to the end because you need to manipulate the servo so it continuously turns in whole circles!!!!

Additional you will also need the following or similar parts:

433mhz Remote controller set:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/1pc-DC-12v-10A-relay-1CH-wireless-RF-Remote-Control-Switch-Transmitter-Receiver-433MHz/32797607030.html

A dc-dc step down converter:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/5-pcs-Mini-360-DC-DC-Buck-Converter-Step-Down-Module-Ultra-Small-Power-Supply-Module/32412017021.html

A small servo:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/1PCS-Tower-Pro-9g-micro-servo-for-airplane-aeroplane-6CH-rc-helcopter-kds-esky-align-helicopter/32273349010.html

9volt battery connector:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-9V-Battery-Snap-Connector-clip-Lead-Wires-Holder-PP3-MN1604-9volt-Black-Battery-Holder-Clip/32738795144.html

Small on/off switch:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/20pcs-Lot-7-7mm-latching-switch-Self-lock-On-Off-button-switch-double-row-self-locking/32818968898.html

9 volt Battery

Soldering iron, wire, hotglue gun, some screws, 2 strong pulling springs, M8 rod + nuts

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AWrwPDyN75A

title: (3D Slash) Generic Action Camera to GoPro Accessory Adapter (drill holes to fit)

description.text:
Customized with 3D Slash!

This basic adapter is meant to allow users to use GoPro accessories (chest mount, selfie stick, etc.) on their generic action cameras. Though it may not be suitable for all instances, simply drilling holes into this adapter in correspondence with holes on generic cameras will let you use the wide range of accessories made specifically for GoPro's fastening system.

30mm x 30mm base plate.

Currently, it yields a very snug fit with GoPro accessories. Drilling of pivot hole and sanding / filing recommended.

author: sevanteenth

title: Pirate Ship Seesaw for Magic Tracks, Neo Tracks, and everything compatible
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
https://youtu.be/IwDyeDHLidY

All parts were printed in the position I uploaded them in.

I printed the ship in two parts due to having a small print bed.
I used Loctite Gel Control Super Glue to glue the two pieces together.
I included a single print ship file for those with a larger bed.

I printed one flag which provides sufficient weight to make the seesaw return to the original position after each car passes through. I included an optional second flag for the opposite side. I have not tested to see if this is too much weight for the seesaw to function normally.

Supports are required for all parts, but very little is necessary.

Works with Magic Tracks, Neo Tracks, and anything else compatible with these.
